content: The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 includes provisions for a Trust Fund, reports on affordability and civil rights violations, technical assistance for rural areas, sewage system improvements, state water pollution control funds, and drinking water grant programs. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States with appropriations from Federal revenues, limited to $34,850,000,000 per fiscal year, and available for expenditures without further appropriation or fiscal year limitation. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States with appropriations from Federal revenues, capped at $34,850,000,000 annually, for purposes outlined in the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund is established with appropriations from Federal revenues for outlined purposes. Section 952 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to define 'subpart F income' for controlled foreign corporations. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will allocate funds from the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund for clean water programs, including grants under various sections of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Administrator will allocate funds from the Trust Fund for clean water programs, including grants under different sections of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Safe Drinking Water Act. The report will cover affordability, discrimination, civil rights violations, public participation in regionalization, and data collection. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct a study on water and sewer services, focusing on water affordability nationwide, including rates, increases, disconnections, and the effectiveness of funding for promoting affordable, equitable, transparent, and reliable water and sewer service. The Administrator will study discriminatory practices and violations by water and sewer service providers receiving Federal assistance regarding civil rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Additionally, efforts to regionalize public water systems and sewer services will be evaluated in terms of public participation. The Administrator will study discriminatory practices and violations by water and sewer service providers receiving Federal assistance regarding civil rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In terms of public participation, efforts to regionalize public water systems and sewer services will be evaluated, including data collection on people living without water or sewer services and water service disconnections due to unpaid charges. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will submit a report to Congress within a year of the enactment of the Act. The report will include the results of a study on discriminatory effects of water service disconnections and recommendations for utility companies, Federal agencies, and States. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO RURAL AND SMALL MUNICIPALITIES AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS. Section 104(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to make grants to nonprofit organizations for providing technical assistance to rural and small municipalities and tribal governments in planning, development, and financing of eligible projects. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide technical assistance and training to rural and small municipalities, tribal governments, and municipalities for publicly owned treatment works and decentralized wastewater treatment systems to protect water quality and ensure compliance with the Act. Information dissemination is also included for those meeting affordability criteria. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to establish a grant program for repairing, replacing, or upgrading residential onsite sewage disposal systems. SEC. 6 addresses state water pollution control revolving funds. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include new requirements for state water pollution control revolving funds. This includes restrictions on providing financial assistance for projects benefiting new communities and the application of section 513 to construction projects funded by the state revolving fund. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow assistance for purchasing privately owned treatment works and canceling management contracts. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act now allows states to use up to 50% of capitalization grants for additional subsidization of publicly owned treatment works. SEC. 7. USE OF STATE REVOLVING LOAN FUNDS UNDER THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT. Section 1452 of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow the use of funds for purchasing privately owned community water systems. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 people and not owned by entities operating other systems to receive assistance. Subsection (d)(2) increases assistance from 30% to 50%, and subsection (g)(3) makes adjustments to paragraph (B). The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to provide guidance for affordable, equitable, transparent, and reliable water and sewer services. It includes protections for households facing disconnection due to unpaid water charges and promotes universal equal access. Assistance in the form of grants is offered to replace lead service lines in private properties. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to provide guidance for affordable, equitable, transparent, and reliable water and sewer services. Assistance is offered to replace lead service lines with lead-free lines. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to establish grant programs for school drinking water improvements and tribal drinking water quality testing.
